name: Apple Inc (AAPL)
facts: Apple was founded in 1976 by Jobs, Wozniak, and Wayne.
Apple Park cost over $5 billion to build.
Apple is known for iPhone, iPad, Mac, etc.

scoreboard.name: Track Record
scoreboard.desc: Consistently beats estimates, strong brand efficiency.

scoreboard.name: Profitability
scoreboard.desc: High margins from premium devices & ecosystem.

scoreboard.name: Revenue Quality
scoreboard.desc: Stable hardware plus high-margin services.

scoreboard.name: Analyst Sentiment
scoreboard.desc: Mostly bullish, strong brand loyalty.

scoreboard.name: Company Viability
scoreboard.desc: Ample cash reserves, unstoppable global presence.

scoreboard.name: Alignment
scoreboard.desc: Privacy & environment stance resonates with consumers.

scoreboard.name: Capital Allocation
scoreboard.desc: Aggressive buybacks, consistent dividend growth.

scoreboard.name: Market Position
scoreboard.desc: Top brand in consumer electronics, unstoppable mindshare.

scoreboard.name: Financial Health
scoreboard.desc: Robust balance sheet, large free cash flow.

scoreboard.name: Outlook
scoreboard.desc: AR/VR expansions, wearables pipeline fueling next wave.

bearBullets: Possible supply chain disruptions or macro slowdown.
Competitors gain traction in smartphones & wearables.
Regulatory scrutiny on App Store fees.
Consumer shifts away from premium pricing in downturn.
baseBullets: Steady iPhone & Mac sales, moderate services expansion.
Wearables keep stable yoy growth, no major surprises.
Emerging markets adopt iOS at a measured pace.
Privacy features maintain baseline brand trust.
bullBullets: AR/VR device sparks new growth category.
Services revenue leaps from subscriptions globally.
Emerging markets embrace Apple brand strongly.
Premium margins sustained by brand loyalty.

qa.a: iPhone remains Apple’s top revenue driver, fueling its ecosystem.

qa.q: How does Apple lead in services?
qa.a: They leverage a huge device base for Apple Music, iCloud, and more recurring revenue.
Speculation about AR/VR headsets; Apple often keeps future plans secret until announcement.
They aim for carbon neutrality in data centers, and incorporate more recycled materials.
Supply chain disruptions, smartphone saturation, and regulatory scrutiny on app store fees.

name: Microsoft Corp (MSFT)
facts: Founded by Bill Gates & Paul Allen in 1975.
Microsoft Office launched in 1990.
Azure is a major revenue driver with strong growth.

scoreboard.name: Track Record
scoreboard.desc: Transformation under Nadella outperforms expectations.

scoreboard.name: Profitability
scoreboard.desc: High margins from software licensing plus Azure returns.

scoreboard.name: Revenue Quality
scoreboard.desc: Enterprise deals plus Office 365 subscriptions.

scoreboard.name: Analyst Sentiment
scoreboard.desc: Wall Street sees stable growth in cloud & enterprise.

scoreboard.name: Company Viability
scoreboard.desc: Dominance in operating systems and productivity suites.

scoreboard.name: Alignment
scoreboard.desc: Open-source contributions, progressive sustainability efforts.

scoreboard.name: Capital Allocation
scoreboard.desc: Steady dividends, large acquisitions (LinkedIn, GitHub).

scoreboard.name: Market Position
scoreboard.desc: Powerhouse in enterprise software, cloud computing.

scoreboard.name: Financial Health
scoreboard.desc: Strong balance sheet with multiple revenue lines.

scoreboard.name: Outlook
scoreboard.desc: Cloud growth, AI integration, potential gaming expansions.

bearBullets: Slow enterprise spending if macro conditions worsen.
Competition from AWS or GCP intensifies.
Regulatory scrutiny on big tech acquisitions.
Legacy Windows business sees declines.
baseBullets: Office 365 and Azure maintain steady yoy growth.
Incremental expansion in gaming, no huge leaps.
Stable enterprise adoption with moderate competition.
Buybacks & dividends keep investor satisfaction.
bullBullets: AI supercharges Office & Azure upsell globally.
Major cloud wins from enterprise deals worldwide.
Activision acquisition expands gaming footprint strongly.
Windows evolves with subscription-based features.

qa.a: AWS leads, while Google Cloud also competes; Azure is second by market share.
Historically yes. Currently regulators watch all big tech including MSFT.
AI integration across Office, Azure expansions, gaming acquisitions.
They aim to buy Activision; previously acquired LinkedIn, GitHub, etc.
Competition from AWS, macro downturn impacting enterprise licensing, potential regulatory hurdles.

name: Meta Platforms (META)
facts: Originally Facebook, started in Harvard dorms, 2004.
Instagram was acquired for $1B in 2012.
WhatsApp was acquired for $19B in 2014.

scoreboard.name: Track Record
scoreboard.desc: Pivoting to metaverse after strong social media ad growth.

scoreboard.name: Profitability
scoreboard.desc: Ads remain profitable, though Reality Labs invests heavily.

scoreboard.name: Revenue Quality
scoreboard.desc: Heavily reliant on digital ads across FB/IG.

scoreboard.name: Analyst Sentiment
scoreboard.desc: Mixed on the metaverse pivot; some remain bullish on VR potential.

scoreboard.name: Company Viability
scoreboard.desc: Giant user base, but public scrutiny & competition from TikTok.

scoreboard.name: Alignment
scoreboard.desc: Privacy & misinformation concerns affect brand trust.

scoreboard.name: Capital Allocation
scoreboard.desc: Heavy AR/VR capex, overshadowing buybacks currently.

scoreboard.name: Market Position
scoreboard.desc: Huge user network effect, uncertain next steps for VR.

scoreboard.name: Financial Health
scoreboard.desc: Strong ad cash flow offsets big R&D, manageable debt.

scoreboard.name: Outlook
scoreboard.desc: Can the metaverse pay off? AR/VR mainstream uncertain.

bearBullets: Spiraling AR/VR costs with no near-term ROI.
Competition from TikTok reduces engagement.
Ad revenue slowdown if macro ad spend declines.
Regulatory crackdowns on data privacy or antitrust.
baseBullets: Gradual metaverse dev, stable social ads yoy.
Instagram Reels offset some short-form competition.
WhatsApp monetization moderate, no big leaps.
User base remains large despite controversies.
bullBullets: Metaverse breakthroughs that attract mainstream users.
VR adoption drives new revenue streams & synergy.
Ad platform evolves to handle short-form effectively.
Global expansions keep FB/IG user growth afloat.

qa.q: How reliant is Meta on ads?
qa.a: Ads still represent the vast majority of revenue, with new attempts at commerce & VR.
Quest devices have traction, but remain niche. Widespread adoption is uncertain.

name: Visa Inc (V)
facts: Visa began as BankAmericard in 1958.
Visa processes transactions in 200+ countries.
Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway owns a stake in Visa.

scoreboard.name: Track Record
scoreboard.desc: Consistent growth as digital payments expand worldwide.

scoreboard.name: Profitability
scoreboard.desc: High margins from transaction-based revenue.

scoreboard.name: Revenue Quality
scoreboard.desc: Reliable transaction fees from card usage globally.

scoreboard.name: Analyst Sentiment
scoreboard.desc: Often a top fintech pick, brand strength in card acceptance.

scoreboard.name: Company Viability
scoreboard.desc: Global market presence, crucial infrastructure, strong moat.

scoreboard.name: Alignment
scoreboard.desc: Fees can be contentious in some regions; invests in fintech.

scoreboard.name: Capital Allocation
scoreboard.desc: Ongoing repurchases, dividends, strategic acquisitions.

scoreboard.name: Market Position
scoreboard.desc: One of the top card networks globally, widely accepted.

scoreboard.name: Financial Health
scoreboard.desc: Steady cash flow, limited debt, healthy margins.

scoreboard.name: Outlook
scoreboard.desc: Growth from e-commerce, digital wallets, emerging markets.

bearBullets: Recession slows consumer spending, transaction volumes dip.
Regional fees disputes or capping hamper profits.
Competition from new fintech solutions.
Global travel declines hamper cross-border fees.
baseBullets: Steady domestic card usage, mild cross-border recovery.
E-commerce expansions offset any in-person slowdown.
Partnerships with banks & merchants remain stable.
Transaction volumes grow in line with normal GDP.
bullBullets: Rapid digital wallet adoption drives more transaction volume.
Cross-border travel surges post-pandemic, boosting fees.
Visa invests in next-gen fintech & crypto rails effectively.
Emerging markets shift away from cash fosters big leaps.

qa.a: MasterCard is the closest, with AmEx & Discover also in the mix.
Primarily from transaction fees between merchants and banks for card usage.

name: Procter & Gamble (PG)
facts: P&G was founded in 1837 by William Procter and James Gamble.
P&G has 60+ individual brands (Tide, Pampers, Gillette).
Big investor in R&D for product innovation.

scoreboard.name: Track Record
scoreboard.desc: Stable performance in consumer staples.

scoreboard.name: Profitability
scoreboard.desc: Strong margins from household brands.

scoreboard.name: Revenue Quality
scoreboard.desc: Repeated consumer purchases, brand loyalty.

scoreboard.name: Analyst Sentiment
scoreboard.desc: Viewed as a defensive stock, stable but slow growth.

scoreboard.name: Company Viability
scoreboard.desc: Global presence, diversified brand portfolio.

scoreboard.name: Alignment
scoreboard.desc: Some sustainability improvements, packaging concerns.

scoreboard.name: Capital Allocation
scoreboard.desc: Dividends, share buybacks, conservative M&A approach.

scoreboard.name: Market Position
scoreboard.desc: Dominant in consumer staples across many categories.

scoreboard.name: Financial Health
scoreboard.desc: Stable cash flow, consistent dividend, strong rating.

scoreboard.name: Outlook
scoreboard.desc: Incremental growth, potential in emerging markets.

bearBullets: Recession hits discretionary spending on branded goods.
Higher commodity costs reduce margins.
Competition from cheaper private labels.
Supply chain issues hamper distribution globally.
baseBullets: Steady staples demand, stable consumer usage yoy.
Brand loyalty keeps existing sales consistent.
Emerging markets offset slower developed market growth.
Slight margin pressure from input costs but manageable.
bullBullets: Strong brand expansions in new segments.
Innovations in sustainability & packaging gain traction.
Pricing power remains unchallenged by private labels.
Emerging market expansions drive above-average yoy growth.

qa.q: Why is P&G seen as defensive?
qa.a: Consumers buy staples even in downturns, stabilizing revenue.

qa.q: Which brand is biggest for P&G?
qa.a: Tide, Pampers, Gillette, Head & Shoulders among major segments.

name: Tesla Inc (TSLA)
facts: Named after Nikola Tesla, founded in 2003.
First Tesla Roadster used Lotus chassis parts.
Giga Berlin & Giga Texas accelerate production.

scoreboard.name: Track Record
scoreboard.desc: Bold timelines, but big EV expansions executed.

scoreboard.name: Profitability
scoreboard.desc: Margins volatile from expansions, but profitable EV sales.

scoreboard.name: Revenue Quality
scoreboard.desc: Global EV demand, plus energy storage solutions.

scoreboard.name: Analyst Sentiment
scoreboard.desc: Varies widely from mega-bull to cautious on valuation.

scoreboard.name: Company Viability
scoreboard.desc: Leader in EV tech, reliant on CEO’s focus though.

scoreboard.name: Alignment
scoreboard.desc: Green mission resonates, controversies from leadership style.

scoreboard.name: Capital Allocation
scoreboard.desc: High spend on Gigafactories, uncertain ROI timeline.

scoreboard.name: Market Position
scoreboard.desc: Dominates EV brand recognition, supercharger network.

scoreboard.name: Financial Health
scoreboard.desc: Improving balance sheet, reliant on new model rollouts.

scoreboard.name: Outlook
scoreboard.desc: Mass EV adoption, new pipeline, potential autonomy.

bearBullets: EV competition saturates market, pressuring margins.
CEO distracted by external ventures & controversies.
Supply chain issues limit production expansions.
Regulatory changes hamper autopilot & data usage.
baseBullets: Steady EV sales yoy, no major disruptions.
New factories in Berlin/Texas ramp moderately.
Solid brand loyalty offsets new entrants.
Autopilot evolves but faces regulatory caution.
bullBullets: Autonomous breakthroughs yield huge new revenue.
Giga expansions meet surging global EV demand swiftly.
Energy storage & solar scale significantly.
Global acceptance of Tesla brand spurs dominating share.

qa.a: Traditional automakers like VW, Ford, plus new EVs like Rivian, NIO ramping up.
Integrated software, supercharger network, brand recognition, plus a first-mover edge.

name: Johnson & Johnson (JNJ)
facts: Founded in 1886, known for baby products.
Has over 250 subsidiary companies worldwide.
Developed an early single-shot COVID-19 vaccine.

scoreboard.name: Track Record
scoreboard.desc: Steady dividends, strong brand trust in medical & consumer.

scoreboard.name: Profitability
scoreboard.desc: Healthy margins in pharma, consumer lines stable.

scoreboard.name: Revenue Quality
scoreboard.desc: Pharmaceuticals, devices, consumer brands diversified.

scoreboard.name: Analyst Sentiment
scoreboard.desc: Generally positive, but large lawsuits weigh some opinions.

scoreboard.name: Company Viability
scoreboard.desc: Massive scale, consistent R&D pipeline, brand trust.

scoreboard.name: Alignment
scoreboard.desc: Healthcare focus is beneficial, controversies in product liability.

scoreboard.name: Capital Allocation
scoreboard.desc: Dividend aristocrat, invests in R&D, spins off occasionally.

scoreboard.name: Market Position
scoreboard.desc: Global leader in pharma & consumer health.

scoreboard.name: Financial Health
scoreboard.desc: Low debt, strong free cash flow.

scoreboard.name: Outlook
scoreboard.desc: Steady growth, expansions in med-tech & new drug pipeline.

bearBullets: Major lawsuits or recalls hamper brand reputation.
Pricing pressures in pharma reduce margins.
Regulatory shifts in medical device approvals.
Slower consumer spending on OTC lines.
baseBullets: Steady pharma & device sales yoy, no major shifts.
Consumer segment stable, incremental product releases.
Emerging markets offset slow growth in developed ones.
Continued dividend reliability for shareholders.
bullBullets: Breakthrough drug approvals drive new revenue streams.
Acquisitions expand med-tech & consumer lines globally.
Litigation resolved favorably, boosting investor confidence.
Brand expansions in emerging markets yield strong yoy growth.

qa.q: Why is J&J a defensive play?
qa.a: Healthcare & consumer staples typically remain in demand during downturns.
Ongoing or potential lawsuits (e.g., talc litigation) can impact finances or brand.

name: NVIDIA Corp (NVDA)
facts: Founded in 1993, focusing on PC graphics initially.
Dominates GPUs for AI, gaming, data centers.
GeForce brand widely recognized among PC gamers.

scoreboard.name: Track Record
scoreboard.desc: Dominates GPU market for gaming & AI.

scoreboard.name: Profitability
scoreboard.desc: High margin chips, cyclical demand from crypto/gaming.

scoreboard.name: Revenue Quality
scoreboard.desc: Gaming, data center, automotive AI provide broad base.

scoreboard.name: Analyst Sentiment
scoreboard.desc: Bullish on AI expansions & HPC solutions.

scoreboard.name: Company Viability
scoreboard.desc: Strong R&D, supply chain constraints are a risk.

scoreboard.name: Alignment
scoreboard.desc: Focus on advanced computing, less on sustainability branding.

scoreboard.name: Capital Allocation
scoreboard.desc: Heavily invests in next-gen GPUs, smaller buybacks.

scoreboard.name: Market Position
scoreboard.desc: Leader in discrete GPUs, key partner for AI.

scoreboard.name: Financial Health
scoreboard.desc: Solid cash, cyclical revenue swings possible.

scoreboard.name: Outlook
scoreboard.desc: AI, data center, automotive expansions fuel next wave.

bearBullets: Gaming demand dips post-pandemic, crypto meltdown reduces GPU sales.
Supply chain issues hamper chip production.
AMD/Intel gain ground in GPU/AI solutions.
Regulatory limits on advanced chip exports hamper big markets.
baseBullets: Sustained gaming & AI demand yoy, stable cyclical patterns.
Data center expansions offset any gaming slowdown.
Steady progress in automotive AI, though moderate.
New GPU generations see typical upgrade cycles.
bullBullets: Explosive AI/hyperscale data center growth driving huge GPU demand.
NVIDIA invests in next-gen HPC solutions, forging new markets.
Automotive advanced driver-assist chips see major adoption.
No major competitor can match brand or performance leadership.

qa.a: AMD in discrete GPUs, Intel in integrated, plus specialized AI chips emerging.
AI, data center HPC, automotive self-driving chips, HPC solutions for research.

name: Netflix Inc (NFLX)
facts: Pioneered streaming, started with DVD-by-mail in 1997.
First original series was Lilyhammer in 2012.
Has over 200 million subscribers worldwide.

scoreboard.name: Track Record
scoreboard.desc: Led streaming revolution, facing new competition.

scoreboard.name: Profitability
scoreboard.desc: Significant content spend, but margins improving.

scoreboard.name: Revenue Quality

scoreboard.name: Alignment

scoreboard.name: Capital Allocation

scoreboard.name: Market Position
scoreboard.desc: Competes with multiple streaming giants, saturating in some markets.

scoreboard.name: Financial Health
scoreboard.desc: High content costs, debt-funded expansions, improved free cash flow recently.

scoreboard.name: Outlook
scoreboard.desc: Ad-supported tier & global expansions keep them afloat, competition is fierce.

bearBullets: Churn rises as new streamers undercut prices.
Expensive content deals don't drive enough subscriber gains.
Global expansions face local/regional competition.
Password-sharing crackdowns alienate some users.
baseBullets: Stable subscriber yoy with moderate new originals.
Ad-supported tier offsets saturated markets.
Content costs remain high but manageable.
Churn minimized by popular returning series.
bullBullets: Hit original franchises spark strong new subscriber waves.
Ad tier becomes a significant revenue stream globally.
International expansions see big net adds yoy.
Creative content deals or gaming tie-ins open new markets.

qa.a: Disney+, Amazon Prime Video, HBO Max, etc. all vying for streaming audiences.
Competition from well-funded rivals, potential saturations in key markets, expensive content arms race.

name: Coca-Cola (KO)
facts: Coca-Cola originated in 1886 as a soda fountain drink.
Over 1.9 billion Coke servings are consumed daily worldwide.
Has many sub-brands like Sprite, Fanta, Minute Maid.

scoreboard.name: Track Record
scoreboard.desc: Decades of stable results, iconic beverage brand.

scoreboard.name: Profitability
scoreboard.desc: Margins from concentrate model, but soda challenges.

scoreboard.name: Revenue Quality
scoreboard.desc: Constant demand for beverages, diversified portfolio.

scoreboard.name: Analyst Sentiment

scoreboard.name: Company Viability

scoreboard.name: Alignment

scoreboard.name: Capital Allocation
scoreboard.desc: Dividend aristocrat, invests in marketing & new beverages.

scoreboard.name: Market Position
scoreboard.desc: Unrivaled brand recognition globally in beverages.

scoreboard.name: Financial Health
scoreboard.desc: Stable free cash flow, moderate debt.

scoreboard.name: Outlook
scoreboard.desc: Soda decline in developed markets offset by new products & emerging markets.

bearBullets: Soda consumption declines faster in health-focused markets.
Sugar taxes or regulations hamper volumes.
Competition from local beverage alternatives in emerging markets.
Currency fluctuations reduce global profit margins.
baseBullets: Steady global footprint, moderate yoy growth in core brands.
Zero-sugar & new flavors offset soda decline somewhat.
Emerging markets remain key growth areas long-term.
Strong marketing keeps brand relevant to younger consumers.
bullBullets: Innovations in new beverage categories see big success.
Zero-sugar lines & premium products gain traction widely.
Marketing tie-ups with major events boost brand further.
Emerging market expansions yield above-average yoy growth.

qa.q: Why is Coke a defensive stock?
